meta.content: Semitransparent Single-Junction and Tandem Solar Cells Using Microcrystalline Silicon for Energy-Harvesting Photovoltaic Windows

Semitransparent solar cells, which can be incorporated in windows, façades, and skylights, change a part of incident light to electric power while allowing the rest to pass through. Improving the conversion efficiency and visible-light transmittance of such devices is a crucial factor for power-generating window applications. Herein, we report the fabrication of semitransparent single-junction and tandem devices using microcrystalline silicon (μc-Si) with front and rear transparent conducting oxide electrodes by plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition. The material properties of the p-doped silicon-carbide (SiC) films and the interfaces between p-layer and intrinsic μc-Si were optimized to enhance the solar cell performance. By using highly crystalline seed layers for the intrinsic μc-Si absorbers and controlling the properties of high-bandgap p-SiC films, high power conversion efficiency (PCE) and average visible transmittance (AVT) of 4.71 and 12.31%, respectively, were simultaneously obtained for the semitransparent devices using 1000-nm-thick μc-Si absorbers. Their performance at different low light intensities was also investigated. The devices showed steady PCEs of 4.37–4.71% at low light intensities (100–21 mW/cm2). Enhanced PCE of 7.51% and AVT of 11.00% are achieved in high-quality semitransparent tandem devices with amorphous silicon and μc-Si subcells. The corresponding tandem solar cells showed further increased PCE of 9.00% under bifacial illumination condition.

div.div:
Photovoltaics (PV) has become growingly substantial in the universal effort to turn the energy consumption from conventional fossil fuels to environment-friendly renewable energies.
(1−3)
Among PV applications, the use of building-integrated PV (BIPV) is expected to be an innovative approach to meet the large-scale demands in urban areas, which require a large amount of electricity.
(4,5)
The BIPV technology can transform buildings from energy consumers to energy producers. BIPV products can be installed on the building skin as construction elements such as windows, facades, and skylights enabling to combine electricity generation with other functions of the building materials.
(6)
Recently, extensive studies have been performed to employ semitransparent thin-film solar cells in BIPV window applications. In these devices, the absorbers are placed between two transparent conducting electrodes through which electricity production and visible-light transmittance are simultaneously achieved.
(7)
Compared to traditional solar devices with metal electrodes, the semitransparent solar devices absorb light simultaneously from both the front and rear sides, thereby generating higher electric power. Visible-light transmittance of ∼10% of the semitransparent solar devices is considered desirable for energy-harvesting solar windows because this provides physical comfort and reduces cooling loads in hot seasons.
(8)

Thin-film photovoltaic cells using amorphous and microcrystalline silicon (a-Si and μc-Si, respectively) as intrinsic (i) absorbing materials have been considered potential low-cost devices owing to the employment of abundant and nontoxic materials and their large-volume production capacity.
(9)
In window applications, these devices have advantages over rivals such as CdTe, dye-sensitized, organic, and perovskite cells. A thin-film Si with a low light absorption coefficient prevents an excessively abrupt change in the visible-light transmittance according to the thickness, making it adjustable. The thin-film Si devices can be prepared at relatively low deposition temperature (≤200 °C), reducing the thermal damage to the transparent conducting electrodes and glass substrates. A high-quality μc-Si can replace a-Si in the solar device owing to superior spectral response in the long-wavelength region and long-term stability against sunlight.
(10)
The μc-Si device also served as a subcell of the tandem solar device with improved efficiency. However, no extensive studies have been performed to develop the high-quality semitransparent devices using μc-Si absorber materials.

Here, we develop the semitransparent μc-Si solar devices with fluorine-doped tin oxide (SnO
2
:F) front and tin-doped indium oxide (In
2
O
3
:Sn) rear contacts by plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD). In the devices with a p–i–n configuration, the properties of the p-type silicon-carbide (SiC) films served as window layers and the interfaces between p-layers and intrinsic μc-Si absorbers strongly affect the resultant electro-optical characteristics of the solar cells. Thus, we focused on their impacts on the cell performance of the semitransparent μc-Si solar devices. Their performance characteristics were also evaluated when illuminated at low light intensities. Finally, we fabricated high-performance semitransparent tandem solar cells using intrinsic a-Si and μc-Si absorbers.

div.div:
According to previous studies,
(12,13)
crystalline evolution from amorphous to microcrystalline phases occurs as the thickness of microcrystalline Si film increases. Before the growth of the microcrystalline phases, defect-rich amorphous layers are formed. Their thicknesses often exceed a few hundreds of nanometers. The defect-rich amorphous layer prohibits the migration of charge carriers in the device, leading to a large reduction in the device performance. During the early growth, the nucleation and growth of the microcrystalline Si films are significantly influenced by the microstructures of the underlying layers. The highly crystalline seed layers promote local epitaxial growth of the films, resulting in a decrease in the thickness of amorphous phases. For the solar device with p–i–n configuration, the intrinsic microcrystalline Si absorbers are fabricated on the p-doped films. Therefore, in this work, highly crystalline seed layers acting as nucleation layers are inserted between the p-doped films and the intrinsic microcrystalline Si absorbers to reduce the thickness of the defect-rich layers in the subsequent growth of intrinsic absorber layers.

div.div:
Semitransparent microcrystalline Si cells with both high PCE and AVT were developed by controlling the material properties of the seed layers for the intrinsic microcrystalline Si absorbers and p-doped window layers. The insertion of the highly crystalline seed layer into the p/i interface reduced the portion of a defect-rich amorphous Si in the early growth of microcrystalline Si film. The FF and
J
SC
increases of 51.29 and 17.79%, respectively, were obtained for the devices prepared with the seed layers. Upon the introduction of the high-bandgap p-doped silicon-carbide instead of the conventional low-bandgap p-doped microcrystalline Si, the semitransparent μc-Si device exhibited an improved PCE of 4.33%, compared to the initial value of 3.65%. This was primarily attributed to the improved
V
OC
and
J
SC
owing to the increases in the built-in voltage and blue spectral response. Further enhancement in the PCE was achieved by the precise control of the dopant amount of the p-doped layers, improving the electrical conductivity while slightly decreasing the spectral response of 350–550 nm. The PCE and AVT of 4.71 and 12.31%, respectively, were obtained for the semitransparent device using a 1000-nm-thick intrinsic μc-Si absorber. Finally, semitransparent a-Si (350 nm)/μc-Si (1000 nm) tandem devices yield high PCEs of 7.51% (
V
OC
= 1.28 V, FF = 69.81%, and
J
SC
= 8.40 mA/cm
2
) and 9.00% (
V
OC
= 1.30 V, FF = 60.73%, and
J
SC
= 11.40 mA/cm
2
) with front side and bifacial illuminations with AVT of 11.00%.

There are four prerequisites when applying all types of thin-film solar cells to power-generating window photovoltaics (PVs): high power-generation efficiency, longevity and high durability, semitransparency or partial-light transmittance, and colorful and aesthetic value. Solid-type thin-film Cu(In,Ga)S2 (CIGS) or Cu(In,Ga)(S,Se)2 (CIGSSe) PVs nearly meet the first two criteria, making them promising candidates for power-generating window applications if they can transmit light to some degree and generate color with good aesthetic value. In this study, the mech. scribing process removes 10% of the window CIGSSe thin-film solar cell with vacant line patterns to provide a partial-light-transmitting CIGSSe PV module to meet the third requirement. The last concept of creating distinct colors could be met by the addn. of reflectance colors of one-dimensional (1D) photonic crystal (PC) dichroic film on the black part of a partial-light-transmitting CIGSSe PV module. Beautiful violets and blues were created on the cover glass of a black CIGSSe PV module via the addn. of 1D PC blue-mirror-yellow-pass dichroic film to improve the aesthetic value of the outside appearance. As a general result from the low external quantum efficiency (EQE) and absorption of CIGSSe PVs below a wavelength of 400 nm, the harvesting efficiency and short-circuit photocurrent of CIGSSe PVs were reduced by only ∼10% without reducing the open-circuit voltage (VOC) because of the reduced overlap between the absorption spectrum of CIGSSe PV and the reflectance spectrum of the 1D PC blue-mirror-yellow-pass dichroic film. The combined technol. of partial-vacancy-scribed CIGSSe PV modules and blue 1D PC dichroic film can provide a simple strategy to be applied to violet/blue power-generating window applications, as such a strategy can improve the transparency and aesthetic value without significantly sacrificing the harvesting efficiency of the CIGSSe PV modules.

Study of the device characteristics of a CdTe solar cell under weak light irradiance (Eirra) is important both for the understanding of the fundamental device physics and for the com. application, where Eirra with intensity much less than one sun is often encountered for an outdoor solar cell module. In this study, CdTe solar cell performance under Eirra as low as 0.015 sun was studied. Both the fill factor (FF) and the open-circuit voltage (Voc) were found to be critically affected by the shunt resistance at low Eirra. The current shunting depends critically on the phys. location of the shunting paths in the CdTe absorber layer. Space-charge limited current (SCLC) was identified to be an important contribution to the shunting current in thin film CdTe solar cell. At an Eirra as low as 0.015 Sun, CdTe solar cell with a high shunt resistance maintained an efficiency of ∼70 to 80% of the value tested at the std. AM1.5 Eirra. The exptl. results showed that polycryst. CdTe thin film solar cell is a good photovoltaic device for elec. power generation at low Eirra. This study provides constructive guidelines for the future design and fabrication of CdTe solar cells.

There are four prerequisites when applying all types of thin-film solar cells to power-generating window photovoltaics (PVs): high power-generation efficiency, longevity and high durability, semitransparency or partial-light transmittance, and colorful and aesthetic value. Solid-type thin-film Cu(In,Ga)S2 (CIGS) or Cu(In,Ga)(S,Se)2 (CIGSSe) PVs nearly meet the first two criteria, making them promising candidates for power-generating window applications if they can transmit light to some degree and generate color with good aesthetic value. The last concept of creating distinct colors could be met by the addn. of reflectance colors of one-dimensional (1D) photonic crystal (PC) dichroic film on the black part of a partial-light-transmitting CIGSSe PV module. Beautiful violets and blues were created on the cover glass of a black CIGSSe PV module via the addn. of 1D PC blue-mirror-yellow-pass dichroic film to improve the aesthetic value of the outside appearance. As a general result from the low external quantum efficiency (EQE) and absorption of CIGSSe PVs below a wavelength of 400 nm, the harvesting efficiency and short-circuit photocurrent of CIGSSe PVs were reduced by only ∼10% without reducing the open-circuit voltage (VOC) because of the reduced overlap between the absorption spectrum of CIGSSe PV and the reflectance spectrum of the 1D PC blue-mirror-yellow-pass dichroic film. To improve their performance, the microstructural, elec., and optical properties of the core component layers including the metal rear reflectors, p- and n-type doped layers, and intrinsic absorber layers were controlled sophistically. To optimize the optical response of a solar cell, specifically designed materials with appropriate optoelectronic properties are needed. Owing to the unique microstructure of doped nanocryst. silicon oxide, nc-SiOx:H, this material is able to cover an extensive range of optical and elec. properties. However, applying nc-SiOx:H thin-films in photovoltaic devices necessitates an individual adaptation of the material properties according to the specific functions in the device. In this study, we investigated the detailed microstructure of doped nc-SiOx:H films via atom probe tomog. at the sub-nm scale, thereby, for the first time, revealing the three-dimensional distribution of the nc-Si network. Furthermore, n- and p-type nc-SiOx:H layers with various optical and elec. properties were implemented as a window, back contact, and an intermediate reflector layer in silicon heterojunction and multi-junction thin-film solar cells with a focus on the key aspects for adapting the material properties to the specific functions. Here, nc-SiOx:H effectively reduced the parasitic absorption and opened new possibilities for the photon management in the solar cells, thereby, demonstrating the versatility of this material. Remarkably, using our adapted nc-SiOx:H layers in distinct functions enabled us to achieve a combined short circuit c.d. of 15.1 mA cm-2 for the two a-Si:H sub-cells in an a-Si:H/a-Si:H/μc-Si:H triple-junction thin-film solar cell and an active area efficiency of 21.4% was realized for a silicon heterojunction solar cell.

Measured and modelled JV characteristics of cryst. silicon cells below one sun intensity have been investigated. First, the JV characteristics were measured between 3 and 1000 W/m2 at 6 light levels for 41 industrially produced mono- and multi-cryst. cells from 8 manufacturers, and at 29 intensity levels for a single multi-cryst. silicon between 0.01 and 1000 W/m2. Study of the device characteristics of a CdTe solar cell under weak light irradiance (Eirra) is important both for the understanding of the fundamental device physics and for the com. application, where Eirra with intensity much less than one sun is often encountered for an outdoor solar cell module. In this study, CdTe solar cell performance under Eirra as low as 0.015 sun was studied. Both the fill factor (FF) and the open-circuit voltage (Voc) were found to be critically affected by the shunt resistance at low Eirra. The current shunting depends critically on the phys. location of the shunting paths in the CdTe absorber layer. Space-charge limited current (SCLC) was identified to be an important contribution to the shunting current in thin film CdTe solar cell. At an Eirra as low as 0.015 Sun, CdTe solar cell with a high shunt resistance maintained an efficiency of ∼70 to 80% of the value tested at the std. AM1.5 Eirra. The exptl. results showed that polycryst. CdTe thin film solar cell is a good photovoltaic device for elec. power generation at low Eirra. This study provides constructive guidelines for the future design and fabrication of CdTe solar cells.
